title: Cheltenham Spa Malvern Road railway station
text:
Cheltenham Spa Malvern Road railway station was a station in the town of <a href="Cheltenham">Cheltenham</a>.
History.
The station was opened by the <a href="Great%20Western%20Railway">Great Western Railway</a> on 30 March 1908, as "Cheltenham Malvern Road". It was provided so that trains along the line to would not have to start and terminate at , which involved a reversal. The station took its name from the road to the north from which a long driveway provided the main means of public access. Unlike the other stations on the line, Malvern Road had a single <a href="island%20platform">island platform</a>, long on the Up side and on the Down side, which was reached by means of a covered footbridge leading from the booking office. The platform served both main running lines, together with a <a href="bay%20platform">bay</a> at the north end into which local branch <a href="GWR%20steam%20rail%20motors">railmotor</a> services to and from reversed before returning to the <a href="Cheltenham%20Spa%20St.%20James%20railway%20station">St. James</a> terminus, which was much closer to Cheltenham town centre. Malvern Road did not have a resident stationmaster, and it was placed under the responsibility of the St. James stationmaster who also took charge of and stations. Stone from the <a href="Cleeve%20Hill%2C%20Gloucestershire">Cleeve Hill</a> quarries was used in the station buildings, while the platform <a href="coping%20%28architecture%29">copings</a> were sourced from <a href="Pontypridd">Pontypridd</a>.
Regular through services from <a href="Birmingham%20Snow%20Hill%20railway%20station">Birmingham Snow Hill</a> to the <a href="West%20of%20England">West of England</a> via <a href="Stratford-upon-Avon%20railway%20station">Stratford</a> and Malvern Road commenced on 1 July 1908 upon the opening of the <a href="North%20Warwickshire%20Line">North Warwickshire Line</a>. These services covered the distance in just over 2½ hours, but did not run to St. James to which a connecting service was provided by Honeybourne locals or the services to and . By April 1910, <a href="Cornishman%20%28train%29">The Cornishman</a> <a href="express%20train">express</a> was calling at Malvern Road as part of its <a href="Wolverhampton%20Low%20Level%20railway%20station">Wolverhampton</a> to service. The suspension of long-distance services for a period towards the end of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> led to the temporary closure of Malvern Road as an economy measure between 1 January 1917 and 7 July 1919. Not long after reopening, the station was renamed "Cheltenham Spa Malvern Road" on 1 February 1925.
To the west of Malvern Road lay several <a href="rail%20siding">loop sidings</a> serving a two-road <a href="Motive%20power%20depot">engine shed</a> and coaling stage. Access to these facilities was controlled by two <a href="signal%20box">signal box</a>es - Malvern Road East to the north, and Malvern Road West to the south. The East box was opened on 15 July 1906 and had 49 levers; it had replaced the Bayshill signal box which had controlled access to a locomotive shed demolished when the line was extended to Honeybourne. The West box was open by June 1908 and had 37 levers; it replaced a temporary box dating from August 1906. The station saw very little goods traffic as most were handled at St. James; a 15-ton <a href="Truck%20scale%23Rail%20weighbridge">weighbridge</a> was nevertheless provided in the yard.
High-speed services between <a href="Bristol%20Temple%20Meads%20railway%20station">Bristol Temple Meads</a> and Birmingham on the <a href="Birmingham%20and%20Gloucester%20Railway">Birmingham to Gloucester line</a> led to a decline in traffic on the Honeybourne line which closed to local passenger services from 7 March 1960. Malvern Road closed on 3 January 1966 to goods and passengers. The Cheltenham to Honeybourne stretch remained open for passenger trains until 1968 and occasional freight traffic until 25 August 1976 when the derailment of a coal train at caused damage to the Down line which was considered uneconomic to repair. Malvern Road West Signal Box had closed on 5 June 1966, with the East Signal Box lasting until 3 November 1970.
Present day.
, the site is now a housing estate of some 100 homes. A long-term goal of the <a href="Gloucestershire%20Warwickshire%20Railway">Gloucestershire Warwickshire Railway</a> is to extend their services towards the present station at <a href="Cheltenham%20Spa%20railway%20station">Cheltenham Spa (Lansdown)</a> (with the intention of offering interchange with rail services on the <a href="Cross%20Country%20Route">Cross Country Route</a>), which would involve passing the site of Malvern Road.
